div1.head: Newspaper clipping, La Tucha, September 26, 1900
div1.p:
The death of Major Cart-
wright on Sunday, of yellow
fever, has caused a perceptible
increase in the panicky feeling
already apparent here and there,
as is perfectly natural, among
the American clerks and officers.
It is a constant fear, accent-
uated by reading a report, every
day or two, of the death of one
more American.

There have not been very
many cases, proportionately,
among Americans, but the mort-
ality has been high. No start-
ling, sudden spread of the fever
has occurred, simply a steady,
determined seeking out of at-
tractive material, an attack, and
a funeral, or one more immune.

The percentage of deaths is
very small as calculated from
the total number of cases, but,
of the Americans seized fully
forty-five per cent do not re-
cover.

Their companions, therefore,
become somewhat anxious about
there own chances, for which they
can hardly be blamed.

But the fact which they must
bear in mind, and act in ac-
cordance with, is that the man
who broods over the risk he is
running, who sees danger lurk-
ing in every glass of water or
cup of coffee, is almost certain
to be attacked and, in the maj-
ority of instances, such men die.

Stamina, determination, cour-
age and steady nerves mean
much in a fight with yellow
fever, but all of these qualities
will be found badly impaired by
the microbe of fear, if it is once
allowed to enter into the thoughts.

Living in a constant state of
uneasiness and terrified appre-
hension will reduce the nervous
system to a condition in which it
cannot be controlled, and the
mental agony caused wears on
the physical organization so sev-
erely that yellow fever is in-
duced, and finds an easy mark.

Certainly, ordinary precautions
are advisable. Chief among these
is to turn a deaf ear to the advice
so freely offered on every hand,
by nearly every youngster who
has been here two hours. They
all land primed with instructions
and suggestions, from people
who, in one hundred cases out of
ninety-five, are totally ignorant
regarding the subject under dis-
cussion, and who base their ad-
vice on hearsay from equally un-
knowing persons, or on the
weird results evolved from their
own imaginations.

Disregard all of this; throw it
aside-and forget it; pay no atten-
tion to the well-meaning but
harmful rot contained in letters
from relatives who are thousands
of miles away and have not the
faintest idea of what the disease
is; forget everything that has
ever been said by people who do
incalculable harm when they
assume to know all about it;
don't sit around and discuss the
possibility of catching the disease;
don't listen to the stories which
some idiots find such pleasure in
repeating, and become morbid
over; don't go to your room and
imagine that you have eveey
sympton ever discovered. Above
all, don't adopt the measures
which will be recommended, as
every man has different sug-
gestions to make, and most of
them are asinine.

If advice is essential, consult
a reputable physician. Don't go
to any of the quacks or cheap
men who are attempting to build
a practice here on the strength of
being American. Ascertain, first,
before being prescribed for, if the
Doctor has compelled with local
laws; compel him to produce his
documents; if he cannot do so,
let him severely alone, as men
who come here with diplomas
from reliable American colleges,
and with inquestionable evidence
of ability and integrity, have no
difficulty in complying with
requirements.

However, consultation with a
physician is not necessary unless
one is really ill. Ordinary pre-
cautions afford as thorough
protection as can be obtained.

Live decently and about as
you would at home; make no
medical changes in your habits;
drink all of the water you want
-- no city has a purer supply
than has this--don't just because
you are away from home and
its influences try to convince the
world of your manhood by
drinking as much whiskey as
your little skin will hold, and
keep away from Havana's house,
of prostitution. They are dan
gerous, and men who frequent them
are running far greater
risks than that of yellow fever
alone, as any Havana physician
can affirm.
